questions.text: A 28-year-old married woman who is anxious to conceive presents with copious vaginal discharge, without any itching. Her last menstrual period was 13 days ago. What is the cause of her vaginal discharge? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Physiological

 

Physiological:

 

  • The discharge described is white with no pruritus and occurs mid-cycle (ovulatory) with a short duration, which is most likely physiological.
  • Increased physiological discharge is common during:
    • Puberty
    • Ovulation
    • Pregnancy
    • Occasionally during the premenstrual phase
  • It may be cervical or vaginal in origin. A speculum examination of the vagina can distinguish between the two. If the discharge is cervical in origin, an excessive mucoid discharge will be visible at the external os.
  • Normal discharge appears clear or white, without any odor or itching, and has a pH of 3.8-4.2.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Candidiasis:

 

  • Typically presents with white, curdy discharge associated with intense itching and vulvar irritation.
  • The discharge often has a cottage cheese-like appearance.

 

Option B. Bacterial vaginosis:

 

  • Characterized by a thin, grayish-white, homogenous discharge with a fishy odor, especially noticeable after intercourse.
  • Itching is less common.

 

Option C. Trichomoniasis:

 

  • Presents with frothy, yellow-green discharge with a strong odor.
  • Associated with vaginal itching, burning, and discomfort during intercourse.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Physiological vaginal discharge is typically clear or white, without odor or itching, and can occur at ovulation, puberty, pregnancy, or occasionally during the premenstrual phase.

 

 

Ref: Page no 554, DC Dutta’s Textbook of gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: Transformation of CLL/SLL into DLBCL is referred to as which of the following? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Richter syndrome

 

Explanation: 

 

Richter syndrome refers to the transformation of chronic lymphocytic leukemia/small lymphocytic lymphoma (CLL/SLL) into diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL). This transformation occurs in approximately 5-10% of CLL/SLL patients and is often heralded by the development of a rapidly enlarging mass within a lymph node or the spleen. Richter syndrome is frequently associated with acquisition of new abnormalities involving TP53 or MYC genes and represents an ominous event, with most patients surviving less than 1 year after transformation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Evans syndrome - This is an autoimmune disorder characterized by the simultaneous or sequential occurrence of autoimmune hemolytic anemia (AIHA) and immune thrombocytopenia (ITP). It has no relation to the transformation of CLL/SLL to DLBCL.

 

Option C. Li-Fraumeni syndrome - This is an inherited cancer predisposition syndrome associated with germline mutations in the TP53 tumor suppressor gene. It is characterized by a high risk of developing various cancers but is not related to CLL/SLL transformation.

 

Option D. Kostmann syndrome - This is a rare congenital disorder characterized by severe neutropenia, leading to recurrent infections. It is unrelated to CLL/SLL transformation and represents a disorder of granulocyte production.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Richter syndrome represents the clinically aggressive transformation of CLL/SLL into DLBCL, characterized by rapidly enlarging masses, new genetic abnormalities, and poor prognosis with survival usually less than one year.

choices.text: Dendritic ulcer on a fluorescein dye

questions.text: What is the characteristic feature of a fungal corneal ulcer?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Satellite lesion

 

Satellite lesions are characteristic of fungal ulcer.

 

The signs of a fungal ulcer include:

  • Irregular margins of the ulcer.
  • Presence of satellite lesions surrounding the ulcer.
  • An immune ring (Wesseley) may be seen around the ulcer due to deposition of the immune complexes.
  • Slough is usually dry, with feathery borders surrounded by a yellow line of demarcation.
  • Hypopyon may be present or absent. If present, it is thick, immobile due to the direct invasion of the fungal hyphae into the anterior chamber.
  • Perforation in mycotic ulcer is rare but can occur.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Reverse hypopyon:  "Reverse hypopyon" can form when emulsified silicone oil used during vitreoretinal surgery enters the anterior chamber of the eye. The silicone oil floats in the aqueous to look like a layered hypopyon in the upper portion of the anterior chamber. Silicone Oil in anterior chamber is called hyperoleon.

 

 

Inverted or reverse hypopyon as a result of emulsification into the anterior chamber. Migration of silicon oil into the anterior chamber displaces aqueous inferiorly and results in a density gradient demarcation line.

 

Option B. Dendritic ulcer on fluorescein dye: Caused by herpes zoster and herpes simplex.

 

Caused by herpes zoster and herpes simplex.

 

 

Pseudodendritic ulcer is caused by acanthamoeba.

 

Option C. Ring abscess: Can be seen in recurrent stromal herpes keratitis or acanthamoeba keratitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Satellite lesions around the main ulcer are characteristic of fungal corneal ulcers, along with irregular margins, immune rings, and potentially immobile hypopyon.

choices.text: Aspiration is an important mode of transmission
Legionella antigens in the urine is the gold standard of diagnosis
Legionnaires' disease is also known as Pontiac fever

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Legionella pneumonia is true? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Aspiration is an important mode of transmission

 

Explanation: 

 

Aspiration is indeed an important mode of transmission for Legionella pneumonia. The text explicitly identifies aspiration as the "predominant mode" of transmission for Legionella. This occurs either via oropharyngeal colonization or directly through drinking contaminated water. This route of infection is more significant than the aerosol transmission that is often associated with Legionnaires' disease outbreaks.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Legionella antigens in the urine is the gold standard of diagnosis - This is incorrect because while urinary antigen testing is a useful and commonly used diagnostic tool for Legionella, it is not described as the gold standard. Culture on specialized media such as Buffered Charcoal Yeast Extract (BCYE) agar is considered the reference method for diagnosis, though it takes longer.

 

Option C. Legionnaires' disease is also known as Pontiac fever - This is incorrect because these are two distinct clinical entities caused by Legionella. Pontiac fever is described as an "acute, flu-like illness" that is "self-limiting, never develops into pneumonia." In contrast, Legionnaires' disease specifically refers to the pneumonic form of infection characterized by "non-productive cough, dyspnea, chest pain, high fever and diarrhea."

 

Option D. High person-to-person transmission - This is incorrect because the text explicitly states "No man-to-man transmission" for Legionella. The bacteria are acquired solely from environmental sources such as contaminated water systems.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Legionella infection primarily occurs through aspiration of contaminated water, with no person-to-person transmission documented, and presents as either Legionnaires' disease (pneumonia) or Pontiac fever (non-pneumonic flu-like illness) depending on the clinical manifestation.

choices.text: Herpes simplex virus
Ebstein Barr virus

questions.text: A patient underwent a renal transplant following which he developed an infection that had owl eye inclusions. What is the likely cause of the finding? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cytomegalovirus

 

The presence of owl eye inclusions in a patient with a history of immunosuppression (such as following a renal transplant) is highly suggestive of cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection.

 

Cytomegalovirus (CMV):

 

  • Pathology: CMV is a member of the herpesvirus family and is a common cause of infection in immunocompromised individuals. The virus causes the formation of characteristic intranuclear inclusions that resemble owl's eyes.
  • Clinical Features: Patients may present with fever, fatigue, and signs of organ-specific involvement, such as pneumonitis, hepatitis, or retinitis, depending on the site of infection.
  • Histopathology: The characteristic finding on histopathology is the presence of large cells with basophilic intranuclear inclusions surrounded by a clear halo, giving the appearance of owl's eyes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Herpes simplex virus: Typically causes vesicular lesions and does not produce owl eye inclusions.

 

Option B. Epstein Barr virus: Associated with infectious mononucleosis and various lymphoproliferative disorders, not typically owl eye inclusions.

 

Option D. HIV: Causes immunosuppression but does not produce characteristic owl eye inclusions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Owl eye inclusions seen in immunocompromised patients, especially post-transplant, are indicative of cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection.

choices.text: Rupture of emphysematous bulla of lung

questions.text: A 45-year-old man arrives at the emergency department, reporting upper abdominal pain that started after consuming a large meal. During the physical examination, there's notable tenderness in the upper abdominal region. Findings from a chest X-ray show an enlargement of the mediastinum and pneumomediastinum. What is the probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Spontaneous perforation of esophagus

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical scenario is suggestive of spontaneous perforation of the esophagus, also known as Boerhaave's syndrome. It occurs due to vomiting against a closed glottis/cricopharynx, leading to a massive rise in esophageal pressure and subsequent perforation. This typically happens on the left lower wall of the esophagus.

 

Clinical Features of Spontaneous Perforation of the Esophagus (Boerhaave's Syndrome):

 

  1. Chest Pain: Sudden and severe pain that may radiate to the back, neck, or abdomen, often exacerbated by swallowing.
  2. Vomiting: Severe vomiting that precedes the onset of pain, leading to esophageal rupture.
  3. Dyspnea or Shortness of Breath: Due to leakage of air and fluids into the chest cavity, causing pleural effusion or pneumothorax.
  4. Subcutaneous Emphysema: Air leaks from the esophagus into the chest wall, causing a characteristic crackling sensation when the skin is palpated.
  5. Shock: Severe cases may lead to shock due to sepsis or hypovolemia.
  6. Hamman's Sign: A crunching or rasping sound synchronous with the heartbeat, heard over the precordium or left lateral chest wall on auscultation, caused by heartbeats displacing air-filled tissues.
  7. Abdominal Pain and Tenderness: Especially if the perforation is near the lower part of the esophagus.
  8. Fever: A response to inflammation and infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Perforation of peptic ulcer: This usually presents with sudden, severe abdominal pain and signs of peritonitis. The diagnosis would typically show free air under the diaphragm on an upright chest X-ray, not mediastinal enlargement and pneumomediastinum.

 

Option C. Foreign body in esophagus: This condition may cause dysphagia, odynophagia, and localized pain but is less likely to present with mediastinal enlargement and pneumomediastinum unless it leads to perforation.

 

Option D. Rupture of emphysematous bulla of lung: This condition can cause sudden chest pain and pneumothorax but does not typically present with pneumomediastinum and is not related to eating or upper abdominal pain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Spontaneous perforation of the esophagus (Boerhaave's syndrome) is characterized by severe chest pain, vomiting, dyspnea, subcutaneous emphysema, and pneumomediastinum, often following severe vomiting. This diagnosis should be considered in patients presenting with these symptoms, especially with radiographic evidence of mediastinal enlargement and pneumomediastinum.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman with epithelial ovarian cancer has peritoneal metastases and ascites. What is the management? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Debulking followed by chemotherapy

 

Explanation:

 

For advanced ovarian cancer with peritoneal metastases and ascites, the preferred treatment is surgical debulking followed by chemotherapy. This approach helps reduce tumor load and enhances chemotherapy effectiveness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Debulking followed by radiotherapy: Radiotherapy is not typically used as a first-line treatment in ovarian cancer with peritoneal metastases.

 

Option C. Chemotherapy followed by debulking: Starting with chemotherapy may be considered, but debulking first is usually preferred.

 

Option D. Staging laparotomy: Staging laparotomy is primarily diagnostic, not therapeutic.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In advanced epithelial ovarian cancer with peritoneal involvement, initial surgical debulking followed by chemotherapy is the standard management approach to maximize treatment efficacy.

questions.text: Which appendicular carcinoma is most commonly associated with pseudomyxoma peritoneii? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mucinous adenocarcinoma 

 

Pseudomyxoma peritonei is a rare condition characterized by the presence of mucinous ascites due to the dissemination of mucus-producing cells within the peritoneal cavity.

 

This is a type of cancer that arises from cells that produce mucus, commonly from the appendix. It is the most common cause of pseudomyxoma peritonei, as these malignant cells can spread throughout the peritoneal cavity and secrete mucin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mucinous cystadenoma: This is a benign ovarian tumor that can produce mucus, but it is less commonly associated with pseudomyxoma peritonei compared to its malignant counterparts.

 

Option C. Carcinoid tumor: Carcinoid tumors are neuroendocrine tumors that can occur in the appendix. While they can spread, they are not typically associated with the production of abundant mucin that characterizes pseudomyxoma peritonei.

 

Option D. Serous cystadenoma: This is a benign tumor that can occur in the ovaries and produce a watery serous fluid, not the mucinous ascites seen in pseudomyxoma peritonei.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Mucinous adenocarcinoma, particularly of the appendix, is the most common appendicular carcinoma associated with pseudomyxoma peritonei, characterized by the accumulation of mucinous material in the peritoneal cavity.

choices.text: ECG to rule out atrial fibrillation
If ECG is normal, CT scan should be done
Vestibular neuritis is a possible condition that can cause these symptoms

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presented with an episode of acute onset dizziness and loss of consciousness which lasted for a few seconds followed by a regain of full consciousness. There were no similar episodes in the past. Which of the following is a true statement regarding this scenario? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. ECG to rule out atrial fibrillation

 

An electrocardiogram (ECG) is crucial in the initial evaluation of a patient presenting with syncope, particularly to rule out cardiac causes such as atrial fibrillation, which can lead to episodic reductions in cardiac output and cerebral perfusion. Atrial fibrillation, a common arrhythmia in the elderly, can cause transient episodes of dizziness and loss of consciousness due to irregular and often rapid heart rate leading to ineffective heart pumping.

 

Note - In an elderly w/ first episode of syncope detailed history, clinical exam (cardiac, postural BP, neuro exam), basic investigations (ECG, +/- ECHO) is required

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. If ECG is normal, CT scan should be done: While a CT scan might be considered if there is suspicion of a neurological cause after a thorough clinical evaluation, it is not automatically the next step following a normal ECG, especially in the absence of neurological symptoms or signs suggestive of structural brain disease.

 

Option C. Tilt-table testing: This is generally reserved for cases where recurrent unexplained episodes of syncope occur, particularly when a vasovagal or orthostatic cause is suspected, not typically used after a first episode unless specific indications are present.

 

Option D. Vestibular neuritis is a possible condition that can cause these symptoms: Vestibular neuritis can cause severe vertigo and imbalance but typically does not cause loss of consciousness, making it less likely in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In elderly patients presenting with an acute onset of dizziness and syncope, an ECG is an essential first step to rule out arrhythmic causes such as atrial fibrillation. Additional diagnostic steps should be guided by the findings of the initial evaluation and specific clinical indicators.

 

Reference - Harrison 21/Atrial fibrillation/Chap 251

choices.text: Kills the sperms in the cervical canal

questions.text: Which of the following is not the mechanism of action of progesterone only pills? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Kills the sperms in the cervical canal

 

Explanation:

 

Progesterone only pills (POPs), also known as mini pills, act through several mechanisms to prevent pregnancy, but they do not kill sperms in the cervical canal.

 

Incorrect. Progesterone only pills do not have a spermicidal effect. They do not kill sperm; instead, they work by altering the cervical mucus and preventing ovulation.

 

The mechanisms of action include:

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thickening the cervical mucus: This makes it difficult for sperm to enter the uterus and fertilize an egg.

 

Option B. Preventing ovulation: Although not as consistently as combined oral contraceptives, POPs can inhibit ovulation in some women.

 

Option D. Inhibiting penetration of sperm: By thickening the cervical mucus and affecting the endometrial lining, POPs inhibit the sperm’s ability to penetrate and fertilize an egg.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Progesterone only pills prevent pregnancy by thickening cervical mucus, inhibiting ovulation, and preventing sperm penetration, but they do not kill sperm in the cervical canal.

 

Ref: Page no 323, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

questions.text: All of the following genetic syndromes associated with colorectal cancer are caused by mutations on the APC gene, except: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lynch Syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

Lynch Syndrome (also known as Hereditary Non-Polyposis Colorectal Cancer or HNPCC) is caused by mutations in DNA mismatch repair genes (MMR genes) - primarily MSH2, MLH1, MSH6, and PMS2, not the APC gene. These germline mutations affect one of the four DNA mismatch repair genes that are components of a repair system responsible for correcting errors in newly replicated DNA.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. FAP (Familial Adenomatous Polyposis): FAP is caused by germline mutations in the APC gene on chromosome 5. Affected individuals develop hundreds to thousands of adenomas in the colon, with inevitable progression to colorectal cancer if prophylactic colectomy is not performed.

 

Option C. Gardner's Syndrome: Gardner's syndrome is a variant of FAP with extracolonic manifestations and is caused by mutations in the APC gene. These manifestations include mandibular osteomas, dermoid tumors, and other features beyond the classic colorectal polyps.

 

Option D. Turcot's Syndrome: Turcot syndrome involves both colorectal polyposis and brain tumors and can result from mutations in the APC gene when it presents as a variant of FAP. Brain tumors typically include medulloblastomas when associated with APC mutations.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

While FAP, Gardner's Syndrome, and Turcot's Syndrome (FAP variant) are all associated with mutations in the APC gene, Lynch Syndrome is uniquely caused by mutations in DNA mismatch repair genes, creating a different phenotype with fewer polyps but rapid progression to malignancy.

choices.text: It is involved in the creation of Okazaki fragments
It is the primary enzyme of DNA synthesis

questions.text: Which of the following is true about DNA polymerase I? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It is found in prokaryotes

 

This statement is correct. DNA polymerase I is primarily found in prokaryotic organisms, including bacteria. In prokaryotes, it plays a crucial role in DNA replication and repair.

 

Additional Information –

 

DNA polymerase I (Kornberg’s enzyme) from Escherichia coli (prokaryote). It is a repair  enzyme. It has both 3′ to 5′ and 5′ to 3′ exonuclease activities. When 5′ to 3′ exonuclease domain is removed, the remaining fragment retains the polymerization and proofreading activities; it is then called Klenow fragment. It is widely used in recombinant DNA technology.

 

DNA polymerases I, II, and III are prokaryotic polymerases.

 

DNA polymerase II: DNA proofreading and repair.

 

DNA polymerase III: Main replication enzyme in bacteria

 

In mammalian cells (eukaryotic), there are 5 DNA polymerases (DNAPs) named as α, β, γ, δ and ε.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is involved in the creation of Okazaki fragments: DNA polymerase I main function is to remove RNA primers from Okazaki fragments and fill the gaps with DNA nucleotides. The synthesis of Okazaki fragments is primarily carried out by DNA polymerase III in prokaryotes.

 

Option C. It synthesizes RNA primers: DNA polymerase I does not synthesize RNA primers. Instead, it removes RNA primers by its 5' to 3' exonuclease activity as part of the primer removal process during DNA replication.

 

Option D. It is the primary enzyme of DNA synthesis: This statement is not true. While DNA polymerase I is involved in DNA replication, it is not the primary enzyme responsible for DNA synthesis. In prokaryotes, DNA polymerase III is the primary enzyme responsible for DNA synthesis during replication.

 

Educational Objective:

 

DNA polymerase I is a critical enzyme found in prokaryotes, involved in DNA replication and repair. While it plays key roles, including the removal of RNA primers from Okazaki fragments, DNA polymerase III is the primary enzyme for DNA synthesis in these organisms

questions.text: Mrs. Kumar, a 60-year-old woman, has been experiencing difficulty swallowing and a feeling of pressure in her chest. Her doctor orders an ultrasound, which reveals a retrosternal goiter. The commonest surgical approach to a retrosternal goiter is via: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Neck

 

Explanation:

 

The commonest surgical approach to a retrosternal goiter is via the neck. This is because the thyroid gland is anatomically located in the neck, and even when a goiter extends behind the sternum into the chest, the neck provides the most direct and least invasive access for surgical removal. The retrosternal portion of the goiter can usually be mobilized and delivered into the neck for excision without the need for more invasive thoracic approaches. The vascular supply of the goiter also predominantly comes from cervical vessels like the inferior thyroid artery, making the neck approach feasible and effective.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Chest: Surgical approaches through the chest are typically not used for retrosternal goiters. Accessing the thyroid gland through the chest would involve more invasive procedures, such as thoracotomy, and is generally reserved for rare cases with specific indications, such as very large goiters extending deeply into the chest cavity.

 

Option C. Median Sternotomy: Median sternotomy involves cutting through the breastbone (sternum) to access structures within the chest, particularly the heart and major blood vessels. While median sternotomy is common for cardiac surgeries, it is not the primary approach for treating retrosternal goiters, which can typically be addressed via the neck.

 

Option D. None of the above: This option is incorrect because the neck is the commonest and preferred approach for the surgical removal of retrosternal goiters.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common and preferred surgical approach for a retrosternal goiter is via the neck due to its direct access to the thyroid gland and the feasibility of mobilizing the goiter from this region.

questions.text: Based on the provided X-ray, what is the diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hollow viscus perforation

 

The X-ray provided shows air under the right diaphragm, which is a clear sign of a hollow viscus perforation, specifically pneumoperitoneum. This occurs when air escapes from the gastrointestinal tract into the peritoneal cavity, typically due to a perforation. The key visual cue here is the presence of air under the right diaphragm, as air under the left diaphragm can sometimes be due to the presence of the stomach and may cause confusion. In the clinical setting, such a finding would correlate with symptoms like acute abdomen, severe pain, guarding, and rigidity.

 

For the diagnosis of conditions like a suspected perforation, the initial and primary investigation recommended is a chest X-ray PA (posteroanterior) in an erect position. While a Contrast-Enhanced CT (CCT) with oral contrast is more sensitive and can precisely locate the site of the leak, it's generally not necessary if the chest X-ray has already confirmed the diagnosis.

 

Upon confirming a perforation, immediate actions include administering IV fluids for resuscitation followed by urgent surgical intervention, typically an exploratory laparotomy, due to the emergent nature of gastrointestinal perforations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Esophageal perforation: While an esophageal perforation could also lead to air escaping into the mediastinum or other areas, it typically presents with pneumomediastinum rather than air under the diaphragm.

 

Option B. SBO (Small Bowel Obstruction): SBO typically presents with dilated loops of bowel and air-fluid levels on an X-ray, rather than free air under the diaphragm.

 

Option D. Volvulus: Volvulus involves twisting of a loop of intestine, which can lead to obstruction and possibly ischemia, but does not usually present with free air under the diaphragm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of air under the right diaphragm on an erect chest X-ray is a strong indicator of a hollow viscus perforation and is considered a surgical emergency

questions.text: A 26-year-old female patient complains of a nodular lesion near the limbus as shown, with mild discomfort that resolves after treatment with the use of a topical drug. What can be the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Episcleritis with Rheumatoid Arthritis

 

Episcleritis is an inflammatory condition affecting the episclera, the layer of tissue lying between the conjunctiva and the sclera. It often presents with a red, nodular lesion near the limbus that causes mild discomfort and responds well to topical treatment, such as phenylephrine, which is a vasoconstrictor. Phenylephrine helps blanch the inflamed vessels, reducing symptoms and improving the appearance of the lesion. Episcleritis is often associated with autoimmune conditions like rheumatoid arthritis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Scleritis with Rheumatoid Arthritis: Scleritis involves deeper inflammation of the sclera and is much more painful compared to episcleritis. It does not resolve with topical treatment alone and often requires systemic therapy. This does not match the scenario of mild discomfort and resolution with topical drugs.

 

Option C. Pinguecula and Dry Eye: Pinguecula is a yellowish, elastotic degeneration of the conjunctiva that typically appears as a quiet, non-inflamed lesion. It does not cause significant discomfort or redness, making this an unlikely diagnosis in the presence of nodular inflammation.

 

 

Option D. Pterygium and Astigmatism: Pterygium is characterized by a wing-shaped growth of conjunctiva that extends onto the cornea, causing astigmatism. Since the lesion in question does not encroach onto the cornea, pterygium is not a suitable diagnosis.

 

 

Educational Objective:


Episcleritis presents as a mildly uncomfortable, nodular lesion near the limbus that responds to topical treatment, such as phenylephrine, and is often associated with autoimmune conditions like rheumatoid arthritis.

questions.text: What are the rounded, depressed regions of necrotic limbal follicles known as? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Herbert's pits

 

Herbert's pits are the rounded, depressed regions that form after the healing of necrotic limbal follicles in trachoma. They represent a characteristic feature of the cicatricial phase of trachoma and remain as permanent sequelae of the disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Von Arlt's line: This is incorrect because Arlt's line refers to a linear scar present in the sulcus subtarsalis (the groove where the palpebral conjunctiva connects with the skin). It is another cicatricial feature of trachoma but is not related to necrotic limbal follicles. Arlt's line forms during the scarring stage of trachoma.

 

Option C. Fuchs' spots: This is incorrect because Fuchs' spots (or islets of Vogt) are whitish infiltrates seen in front of the head of a progressive pterygium. They are unrelated to trachoma or necrotic limbal follicles, being instead associated with pterygium formation.

 

Option D. Horner-Trantas dots: This is incorrect because Horner-Trantas spots are discrete whitish raised dots along the limbus seen in vernal keratoconjunctivitis. They represent eosinophilic accumulations at the limbus, not necrotic follicles. They are characteristic of allergic conjunctival disease, not trachomatous infection.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Herbert's pits are pathognomonic scarring lesions of trachoma that form at the limbus after healing of Herbert's follicles, appearing as oval or circular pitted scars that persist as permanent markers of previous trachomatous infection.

questions.text: According to World Health Organization (WHO), blindness is defined as: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) VA < 3/60

 

According to the World Health Organization (WHO), blindness is defined as visual acuity less than 3/60 in the better eye with the best possible correction. This definition has been in place since 2017 and has also been adopted by India’s National Program for Control of Blindness and Visual Impairment (NPCBVI). The definition includes three criteria, any of which can classify a person as blind:

 

  1. Visual acuity less than 3/60 in the better eye with best correction possible
  2. Visual field less than 10 degrees
  3. Inability to count fingers at 3 meters

 

Note – VA < 6/60 was the old Indian criteria for blindness before 2017, where visual acuity less than 6/60 and visual field less than 20 degrees were considered blind. However, this is no longer the current WHO or Indian standard.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The WHO definition of blindness, adopted since 2017, is visual acuity less than 3/60 in the better eye with best possible correction, or visual field less than 10 degrees, or inability to count fingers at 3 meters.

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with varicose veins comes to OPD with complaints of eczema over the same region. What is the stage of the clinical classification according to the CEAP guidelines? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) C4a

 

  • The descriptive CEAP (Clinical-Etiology-Anatomy-Pathophysiology) classification for chronic venous disorders is as follows:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. C2:

 

  • Description: Varicose veins without any additional skin changes or complications.
  • Why Incorrect: The patient has eczema, which indicates a more advanced stage than C2.

 

Option B. C3:

 

  • Description: Presence of oedema without skin changes.
  • Why Incorrect: The patient has eczema, not just oedema.

 

Option D. C4b:

 

  • Description: Lipodermatosclerosis or atrophie blanche.
  • Why Incorrect: The patient has eczema, which is classified under C4a, not the more severe skin changes seen in C4b.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • According to the CEAP classification for chronic venous disorders, the presence of eczema or pigmentation in a patient with varicose veins is classified as stage C4a.

questions.text: Disorders resulting from defects in nucleotide excision repair include all of the following except: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Ataxia Telangiectasia (AT)

 

Explanation:

 

Ataxia telangiectasia is not a disorder resulting from defects in nucleotide excision repair. It is instead caused by mutations in the ATM gene (Ataxia Telangiectasia Mutated), which is involved in DNA double-strand break repair pathways. The ATM protein functions as a cell cycle checkpoint kinase that phosphorylates and activates proteins involved in DNA damage response. This condition is characterized by progressive cerebellar ataxia, oculocutaneous telangiectasia, immunodeficiency, and increased risk of malignancies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Xeroderma Pigmentosum (XP) - This is correctly associated with defects in nucleotide excision repair. XP is characterized by extreme sensitivity to UV light, resulting in severe sunburns, pigmentation changes, and a high risk of skin cancers. It is caused by mutations in genes encoding proteins involved in nucleotide excision repair.

 

Option B. Cockayne syndrome (CS) - This is correctly associated with defects in nucleotide excision repair. Specifically, it involves defects in transcription-coupled nucleotide excision repair. CS is characterized by growth failure, premature aging, and neurological abnormalities.

 

Option C. Trichothiodystrophy (TTD) - This is correctly associated with defects in nucleotide excision repair. TTD is characterized by brittle hair with low sulphur content, intellectual disability, short stature, and ichthyosis. It results from mutations in genes involved in both nucleotide excision repair and transcription.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

While Xeroderma Pigmentosum, Cockayne syndrome, and Trichothiodystrophy all result from defects in nucleotide excision repair pathways, Ataxia Telangiectasia involves a distinct DNA repair mechanism related to double-strand break repair through the ATM gene.

questions.text: What is the most likely underlying condition associated with the Graham Steell murmur? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pulmonary regurgitation

 

Explanation:

 

Graham Steell murmur is a characteristic early diastolic murmur caused by pulmonary regurgitation in the setting of pulmonary hypertension. It occurs when increased pulmonary artery pressure causes dilation of the pulmonary valve ring, leading to incompetence and regurgitation. The murmur is best heard in the left second or third intercostal space and is characterized as an early diastolic, high-pitched, blowing murmur that decreases in intensity during inspiration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ventricular septal defect (VSD): Produces a pansystolic murmur heard best at the left lower sternal border. A small VSD producing a loud murmur is called Maladie de Roger, not Graham Steell murmur.

 

Option C. Pulmonary stenosis: Produces an ejection systolic murmur best heard in the pulmonary area (left upper sternal border). It does not produce a diastolic murmur, which is characteristic of Graham Steell murmur.

 

Option D. Mitral stenosis: Produces a mid-diastolic murmur best heard at the apex, with presystolic accentuation. It is associated with rheumatic heart disease and does not cause an early diastolic murmur characteristic of Graham Steell.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Graham Steell murmur is a high-pitched early diastolic murmur caused by pulmonary regurgitation in the setting of pulmonary hypertension.

questions.text: Ammonia is transported from the brain to the liver in the form of which of the following amino acids? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Glutamine

 

Explanation

 

Ammonia is transported from the brain to the liver primarily in the form of glutamine.

This is because glutamine can safely carry ammonia through the bloodstream to the liver, where the urea cycle converts it into urea for excretion.

The liver's urea cycle is the primary site for detoxifying ammonia, a neurotoxic byproduct of amino acid metabolism.

Glutamine plays a crucial role in this process by acting as a carrier molecule that neutralizes ammonia, thus preventing its accumulation and potential toxicity in the brain.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glutamate: While glutamate is involved in ammonia metabolism, it is not the primary transporter of ammonia from the brain to the liver. Instead, glutamate is often converted to glutamine for this purpose.

 

Option B. Alanine: Alanine transports ammonia primarily from muscle tissues to the liver. It is part of the glucose-alanine cycle, which helps in the conversion of pyruvate to glucose in the liver.

 

Option C. Glycine: Glycine does not play a significant role in ammonia transport from the brain to the liver.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glutamine is the primary amino acid responsible for transporting ammonia from the brain to the liver.

choices.text: A – Apocrine sweat gland, B – Arrector pilorum, C – Eccrine sweat gland, D – Sebaceous gland
A – Arrector pilorum, B – Apocrine sweat gland, C – Eccrine sweat gland, D – Sebaceous gland
A – Sebaceous gland, B – Eccrine sweat gland, C – Arrector pilorum, D – Apocrine sweat gland
A – Eccrine sweat gland, B – Arrector pilorum, C – Sebaceous gland, D – Apocrine sweat gland

questions.text: Which of the following correctly identifies the skin appendages labeled A to D in the given histological image? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) A – Eccrine sweat gland, B – Arrector pilorum, C – Sebaceous gland, D – Apocrine sweat gland

 

In the image provided, several distinct structures of the skin are labeled:

 

A (Eccrine sweat gland): Eccrine sweat glands are small, coiled glands located superficially in the dermis. They are responsible for temperature regulation through sweat secretion. In the image, A is identified as the eccrine sweat gland, which appears closer to the skin surface compared to the apocrine gland.

 

B (Arrector pilorum): This is a small muscle attached to the hair follicle known as the arrector pilorum. It is responsible for causing hair to stand up during cold or emotional stress, leading to goosebumps.

 

C (Sebaceous gland): These glands are associated with hair follicles and secrete sebum, an oily substance that lubricates the skin and hair. In the image, C is correctly identified as the sebaceous gland.

 

D (Apocrine sweat gland): Apocrine sweat glands are located deeper in the dermis or hypodermis and are associated with hair follicles. They produce a thicker, milky secretion that contributes to body odor when broken down by bacteria. D is correctly labeled as the apocrine sweat gland, which is found deeper compared to eccrine glands.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Eccrine sweat glands are located closer to the skin surface, arrector pilorum is a small muscle connected to hair follicles, sebaceous glands produce sebum and are linked to hair follicles, while apocrine sweat glands are deeper and secrete a thicker fluid associated with hair follicles.

questions.text: A 23-year-old hypertensive man comes to the hospital, on examination, BP was 150/90 mmHg, and was afebrile. On further evaluation, serum renin was found to be normal. He was diagnosed with Conn’s Syndrome. All are true about the Conn’s Syndrome except: (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Metabolic acidosis

 

Explanation:

 

Conn’s Syndrome, also known as primary hyperaldosteronism, is characterized by the excessive secretion of aldosterone. Aldosterone increases sodium reabsorption in the kidneys, leading to water retention, hypervolemia, and subsequently, hypertension. Additionally, aldosterone promotes the secretion of potassium and hydrogen ions via the renal tubules.

 

Other Options:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Conn’s Syndrome is characterized by excessive aldosterone secretion leading to metabolic alkalosis, hypertension, and low renin levels.

questions.text: Laryngismus stridulus is caused by deficiency of:  (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitamin D

 

Laryngismus stridulus is a characteristic feature of severe rickets, which is caused by vitamin D deficiency. In severe cases of rickets, profound vitamin D deficiency leads to significant hypocalcemia. This low calcium level can cause muscle spasms, including spasm of the larynx, resulting in laryngismus stridulus. The condition is characterized by sudden, brief episodes of stridor (high-pitched breathing sound) due to laryngeal spasm.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Vitamin A: Incorrect. While vitamin A deficiency can cause various health issues, including night blindness and increased susceptibility to infections, it is not associated with laryngismus stridulus or rickets.

 

Option C. Vitamin K: Incorrect. Vitamin K deficiency primarily affects blood clotting and is not related to the development of rickets or laryngismus stridulus.

 

Option D. Vitamin C: Incorrect. Vitamin C deficiency (scurvy) causes problems with collagen formation, leading to issues like easy bruising and poor wound healing, but it does not cause rickets or laryngismus stridulus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Laryngismus stridulus is a manifestation of severe rickets caused by vitamin D deficiency, resulting in hypocalcemia and laryngeal muscle spasms.

questions.text: Truck driver presents with painful genital ulcers as shown in the picture. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chancroid

 

Chancroid, caused by the bacterium Haemophilus ducreyi, presents as painful genital ulcers. The ulcers are typically soft, with irregular borders and a base that may be covered with a gray or yellowish material. The presence of multiple, painful ulcers with some slough and pus is characteristic of chancroid. It is important to differentiate chancroid from other sexually transmitted infections that present with genital ulcers.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chancre: A chancre is the primary lesion of syphilis, caused by Treponema pallidum. It is typically a solitary, painless ulcer with a clean base and indurated margins. This does not match the description or appearance of the ulcers in this case.

 

Option C. Donovanosis: Also known as granuloma inguinale, this condition is caused by Klebsiella granulomatis. It presents with painless, beefy-red granulomatous ulcers that tend to bleed easily. The ulcers in the image are not consistent with this description.

 

Option D. Lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV): LGV is caused by certain serotypes of Chlamydia trachomatis. It typically presents with painless genital ulcers followed by painful inguinal lymphadenopathy (buboes). The ulcers themselves are not painful, which differentiates it from chancroid.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chancroid is characterized by painful genital ulcers with irregular borders and a base that may be covered with slough or pus, caused by Haemophilus ducreyi.

choices.text: Point B is 3 cm lateral to point A
Point A is 2 cm above the external os and 5 cm lateral to the internal uterine canal
Point A receives a dose of 7000 cGy
Point B receives a dose of 6000 cGy

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman diagnosed with carcinoma cervix stage 2B was advised radiotherapy. Which of the following statements regarding radiotherapy is false? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Point A is 2 cm above the external os and 5 cm lateral to the internal uterine canal

 

Point A

 

  • A point 2 cm lateral and 2 cm superior to the external cervical os.
  • Represents the anatomical location of the ureter.
  • The total dose to point A should not exceed 8000 cGy.

 

Point B

 

  • A point 3 cm lateral to point A.
  • Represents a dose to the pelvic wall.
  • The dose to point B is about 25 – 30% of the dose to point A (4500 – 6500 cGy).

 

False Statement Explanation

 

  • Point A is 2 cm above the external os and 5 cm lateral to the internal uterine canal:
    • This statement is false because Point A is defined as 2 cm lateral and 2 cm superior to the external cervical os, not 5 cm lateral.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Point A in cervical cancer radiotherapy is located 2 cm lateral and 2 cm superior to the external cervical os, and the total dose should not exceed 8000 cGy.

 

Ref: Page no 350, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

choices.text: Asking the patient to void and see if the pessary is in place
Seeing if the patient feels any discomfort, which means that the pessary is retained
Asking the patient to perform the Valsalva manuever and see if the pessary is in place
Being able to admit two fingers between the ring and the pessary

questions.text: Which of the following is the first step after fitting the pessary to check if the pessary is adequately retained? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Asking the patient to perform the Valsalva maneuver and see if the pessary is in place

 

Explanation:

 

 

 

A vaginal pessary is a device used to support the pelvic organs in women with uterovaginal prolapse who are either unfit for surgery or unwilling to undergo surgery. The fitting process involves several steps to ensure the pessary is comfortable and effective:

 

  1. Patient Preparation: The patient is positioned in the lithotomy position and should have an empty bladder and rectum.
  2. Vaginal Examination: An assessment of vaginal length and width is performed to estimate the appropriate pessary size.
  3. Insertion: The pessary is lubricated and inserted in a cephalad direction against the posterior vaginal wall.
  4. Placement Check: An index finger is directed into the posterior vaginal fornix to ensure the cervix is above the pessary, and the pessary should fit snugly against the vaginal walls without causing pain.
  5. Adequacy Check: The patient is asked to perform a Valsalva maneuver (forceful exhalation against a closed airway) to see if the pessary remains in place, ensuring it is not dislodged during increased intra-abdominal pressure.
  6. Functionality Check: The patient should be able to stand, walk, cough, and urinate without difficulty or discomfort.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Asking the patient to void and see if the pessary is in place: While checking the ability to void is important, it is not the first step after fitting the pessary.

 

Option B. Seeing if the patient feels any discomfort, which means that the pessary is retained: Patient comfort is crucial, but discomfort does not necessarily mean the pessary is adequately retained.

 

Option D. Being able to admit two fingers between the ring and the pessary: This is not a standard method for checking the fit of a pessary.

 

Educational Objective:

 

After fitting a pessary, the first step to check if it is adequately retained is to ask the patient to perform the Valsalva maneuver and see if the pessary remains in place.

questions.text: In the shown image, which one of the following is a source of vitamin B1? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A

 

Vitamin B1 (thiamine) is primarily found in whole grains, cereals, nuts, and legumes. The primary source of thiamine in grains is the aleurone layer, which is often removed during the polishing process of white rice. However, parboiling rice can help preserve this layer, retaining the vitamin B1 content. In the provided image, the food item labeled 'A' is rice, which is a source of vitamin B1, especially when not overly polished.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. This option does not represent a significant source of vitamin B1. It appears to be a different food item that does not contain high levels of this vitamin.

 

Option C. The item labeled 'C' is not a grain or a food typically high in vitamin B1.

 

Option D. This option is also not a significant source of vitamin B1, as it does not represent a grain or similar food known for its thiamine content.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin B1 is primarily found in the aleurone layer of grains, which can be removed by polishing but is preserved in parboiled rice.

questions.text: What among the options serves as a factor that conditions to the development of malnutrition? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Infectious diseases

 

Infectious diseases act as conditioning influences that contribute to the development of malnutrition. They can exacerbate malnutrition by increasing morbidity, leading to decreased food intake, loss of nutrients, anorexia, and overall growth failure, which in turn lowers immunity and creates a vicious cycle of poor health.

 

Other 3 Options are not considered as a conditioning influence.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Identify the structures as marked in the image: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Errector pili muscle

 

In the image, the marked structure corresponds to the Errector pili muscle (C).

Errector Pili Muscle is a tiny muscle attached to the base of a hair follicle. When this muscle contracts, it causes the hair to stand upright, a phenomenon known as "goosebumps."

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sebaceous glands: Incorrect because the sebaceous glands are associated with hair follicles, but the marked structure is clearly a muscle, not a gland. Sebaceous Glands are small oil-producing glands present in the skin of mammals. They are usually associated with hair follicles and release sebum, which helps to lubricate the skin and hair.

 

Option B. Eccrine glands: Incorrect because these glands open directly onto the skin surface without any connection to the hair follicle, whereas the marked structure is connected to a hair follicle. Eccrine Glands are sweat glands that are not associated with hair follicles and play a key role in thermoregulation by secreting sweat.

 

Option D. Apocrine glands: Incorrect because apocrine glands are larger and typically located deeper in the dermis. These are sweat glands usually associated with hair follicles in areas such as the armpits and groin. They secrete a thicker, milky sweat that, when broken down by bacteria, can produce body odor.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Errector pili muscle is a small muscle attached to hair follicles responsible for causing hairs to stand on end when contracted, leading to "goosebumps."

questions.text: What is the side effect of PG analogue Latanoprost? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hyperemia

 

Explanation: 

 

Prostaglandin (PG) analogues are commonly used first-line medications for glaucoma treatment. The most characteristic side effect of these medications is hyperemia, which is redness or inflammation of the conjunctiva. This occurs because prostaglandin analogues are inflammatory mediators that can cause local vascular changes and conjunctival irritation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Orbital cellulitis: Incorrect. PG analogues do not cause orbital cellulitis, which is an infection of the orbital tissues.

 

Option C. Uveitis: Incorrect. While PG analogues are contraindicated in patients with existing uveitis (as they might worsen the condition), they do not directly cause uveitis by themselves. They are, in fact, very rarely associated with uveitis as a side effect.

 

Option D. Keratitis: Incorrect. Similar to uveitis, PG analogues are contraindicated in patients with existing keratitis, but they do not directly cause keratitis. Patients with pre-existing keratitis might find their condition worsened, but the medication itself does not induce keratitis.

 

Educational Objective: 


Latanoprost, a prostaglandin analogue used for glaucoma, commonly causes conjunctival hyperemia, iris pigmentation changes, and eyelash growth. Hyperemia is the most frequently reported side effect.

questions.text: The appearance of saphenofemoral junction on USG, showing common femoral vein, common femoral artery and the great saphenous vein is called as:(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Mickey mouse sign

 

Explanation:

 

The Mickey Mouse sign is the normal anatomy of the common femoral artery, common femoral vein and great saphenous vein on ultrasound at the saphenofemoral junction.

 

 

Mickey mouse sign: Normal SFJ

 

IOC for varicose veins, SFJ incompetence: Doppler USG

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: String sign results from a severe narrowing of a bowel loop, which makes the lumen resemble a string. Seen in case of Pyloric stenosis.

 

 

Option B: Tillaux sign is positive in the case of mesenteric cyst. It is described as a mass lesion of the abdomen which is only mobile in the horizontal and not in vertical direction.

 

Option D: Stemmer sign is seen as non-pitting edema in cases of lymphedema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "Mickey Mouse sign" on ultrasound is a useful anatomical descriptor for the normal configuration of the saphenofemoral junction, aiding in the assessment and diagnosis of venous issues at this location.

questions.text: A 30-year-old pregnant woman with a history of chronic sun exposure presented with bilateral brownish pigmentation over the face as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Melasma

 

Melasma is characterized by bilateral, symmetrical brownish pigmentation, primarily on the face, commonly seen in pregnant women or individuals with chronic sun exposure. In this case, the patient's history of pregnancy and chronic sun exposure, along with the image showing patchy pigmentation, strongly suggests melasma. Melasma in pregnant women is often referred to as chloasma or the "mask of pregnancy." It is associated with hormonal changes and UV exposure. Additionally, melasma is often linked to thyroid disorders.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Melanoma: Melanoma is typically characterized by the ABCDE features: Asymmetry, Border irregularity, Color variation, Diameter greater than 6mm, and Evolution of the lesion.

 

 

Option C. Suntan: A suntan results in diffuse pigmentation over sun-exposed areas, usually with an initial red phase. The pigmentation in a suntan is not patchy as seen in the image provided but rather more uniform. Therefore, suntan is not the correct diagnosis.

 

 

Option D. Nevus of OTA: This condition presents with unilateral blue or grey pigmentation, often involving the sclera and skin on the face. The absence of these characteristic features and the presence of bilateral brown pigmentation make Nevus of OTA an incorrect choice.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Melasma, especially in pregnant women, presents as bilateral, symmetrical brownish patches on the face, often linked to sun exposure and hormonal changes.

questions.text: A 30-year-old drug addict presents to the emergency department with signs of unknown drug poisoning. The patient exhibits dilated pupils, diaphoresis, tachycardia, and tremors. On examination, the blood pressure is 160/100 mmHg, and the heart rate is 120 beats per minute. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cocaine intoxication

 

The patient’s symptoms—dilated pupils, diaphoresis (sweating), tachycardia (elevated heart rate), hypertension (elevated blood pressure), and tremors—are indicative of increased sympathetic nervous system activity.

 

Cocaine is a powerful stimulant that inhibits the reuptake of norepinephrine, dopamine, and serotonin in the central nervous system. This leads to an accumulation of these neurotransmitters in the synaptic cleft, which results in the heightened sympathetic activity seen in the patient, such as increased heart rate, blood pressure, and dilated pupils. Additionally, cocaine use can cause hyperthermia and diaphoresis, further supporting the diagnosis of cocaine intoxication.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dhatura poisoning: While Dhatura poisoning can cause dilated pupils and tachycardia, it is also associated with anticholinergic effects like dry mouth, dry skin, and urinary retention. The presence of diaphoresis and tremors makes Dhatura poisoning less likely because Dhatura poisoning typically presents with decreased sweating (anhidrosis) rather than increased sweating.

 

Option C. Cannabis poisoning: Cannabis typically causes symptoms like euphoria, dry mouth, conjunctival injection (red eyes), and sometimes mild tachycardia. It does not usually cause the severe sympathetic overactivity described in this case, making it an unlikely diagnosis.

 

Option D. Alcohol intoxication: Acute alcohol intoxication generally causes central nervous system depression rather than stimulation. Symptoms may include slurred speech, impaired coordination, and in severe cases, respiratory depression. Alcohol does not cause the significant sympathetic stimulation seen in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cocaine intoxication should be suspected in patients presenting with symptoms of increased sympathetic activity, such as dilated pupils, diaphoresis, tachycardia, hypertension, and tremors. Cocaine acts as a potent stimulant by inhibiting the reuptake of norepinephrine, leading to these clinical signs.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chronic pancreatitis

 

Chronic pancreatitis is characterized by the presence of calcifications along the pancreas, which is a hallmark sign visible on imaging. The X-ray shows calcification along the pancreas, which is indicative of chronic inflammation and fibrosis due to ongoing damage to the pancreatic tissue. These calcifications are a classic sign of chronic pancreatitis and help differentiate it from other conditions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wolman disease: Wolman disease is a rare genetic disorder characterized by calcifications in the adrenal glands due to a deficiency in lysosomal acid lipase. The calcifications in Wolman disease appear near the adrenal glands, which are located superiorly to the kidneys, rather than along the pancreas.

 

Option C. Acute pancreatitis: Acute pancreatitis typically presents with inflammation of the pancreas but does not usually involve calcification. Acute cases are seen with other signs of inflammation like fluid collections but not chronic calcifications.

 

Option D. TB Tuberculosis: Tuberculosis rarely shows calcification on a plain abdominal X-ray unless there is involvement of specific abdominal lymph nodes or organ involvement like the adrenal glands. Pancreatic calcification is not a typical feature of TB.

 

Educational Objective:


Chronic pancreatitis is characterized by pancreatic calcifications on imaging, which are absent in acute pancreatitis and other conditions like Wolman disease or TB.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presented after a motor vehicle accident to the emergency. On examination, the right lower limb was longer than the left, abducted and externally rotated. What can be the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anterior hip dislocation

 

ANTERIOR HIP DISLOCATION

 

  • Anterior dislocations occur with the hip externally rotated and abducted.
  • The degree of flexion at the time of injury determines the eventual position of the femoral head.
  • They are associated with lengthening.
  • Hip dislocations are most common in young adult males and are most often the result of motor vehicle accidents. 
  • The patients present with hip and leg in extension, abduction, and external rotation.

 

 

  • Radiological findings include loss of congruence of femoral head with acetabulum, disruption of shenton's line, femoral head appears larger than contralateral femoral head, and femoral head lies medial or inferior to acetabulum.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Femoral nerve injury: Femoral nerve damage can occur from an injury or prolonged compression. Typically, damage and dysfunction of the femoral nerve are associated with the leg weakness and sensation changes. Injury of the femoral is uncommon but may be injured by a stab, gunshot wounds, or a pelvic fracture. It can also be damaged during hip replacement, abdominal, and pelvic surgeries. The patient presents with poor flexion of the hip because of paralysis of the iliacus, psoas and sartorius muscles. There is an inability to extend the knee because of paralysis of the quadriceps femoris. There is sensory decline over the anterior and medial aspects of the thigh, medial side of the leg and foot up to the first metatarsophalangeal joint. It does not directly affect the position of the hip or the length appearance of the limb.

 

Option B. Femoral neck fracture: Femoral neck fractures are a specific type of intracapsular hip fracture. The junctional location makes the femoral neck prone to fracture. It is commonly seen in the elderly due to low energy falls, and in young patients who perform athletics or due to high-energy trauma. The patient complains of pain with a decreased range of motion of the hip. In non-displaced fractures, there may be no deformity. However, displaced fractures may present with a shortened and externally rotated lower limb. The leg appears shortened due to the upward movement of the distal fragment. The key feature is the inability to bear weight and immediate pain.

 

 

Option C. Posterior hip dislocation: It is the Most common hip dislocation (90%). Patients with a posterior dislocation of the hip generally present with a shortened, internally rotated, adducted limb in slight flexion. If the hip is adducted at the time of injury, a pure dislocation occurs, whereas a neutral position or abduction leads to fracture dislocation. It is associated with a fracture of the femoral head or acetabulum.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The limb appears lengthened and in FABER (flexion, abduction, external rotation) deformity in anterior dislocation of the hip following a motor vehicle accident.
  • Thus, in the given scenario, the patient has anterior dislocation of the hip.

questions.text: During periods of starvation, which of the following tissues primarily utilizes ketone bodies as an energy source? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Brain

 

Explanation:

 

The brain is the primary tissue that utilizes ketone bodies as an energy source during starvation. When glucose levels are low during prolonged fasting or starvation, the brain shifts from relying on glucose to using ketone bodies (acetoacetate and β-hydroxybutyrate) as its main fuel source. The brain can derive up to 75% of its energy requirements from ketone bodies during prolonged starvation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Erythrocytes: Erythrocytes (red blood cells) lack mitochondria and therefore cannot utilize ketone bodies, which require mitochondrial metabolism. They rely exclusively on glucose via glycolysis for their energy needs.

 

Option C. Liver: The liver is the main site of ketone body production but cannot utilize ketone bodies itself because it lacks the enzyme thiophorase, which is necessary for ketone body utilization.

 

Option D. All of the above: This is incorrect because both erythrocytes and liver cannot utilize ketone bodies as explained above.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

During starvation, the brain adapts to use ketone bodies as an alternative fuel source when glucose is limited, while the liver produces but cannot use ketone bodies, and erythrocytes remain dependent on glucose metabolism.

questions.text: Which of the following is related to Navjat Shishu Suraksha Karyakram?(FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Newborn

 

Navjat Shishu Suraksha Karyakram (NSSK) is a program focused on the care of newborns or neonates, which refers to the first 7 days of life. The term "Navjat Shishu" itself means "early newborn" or "neonate."

 

NSSK is a training program designed for healthcare personnel at all levels, aiming to improve newborn care and resuscitation practices. It is a component of the Reproductive and Child Health (RCH) program under the National Rural Health Mission (NRHM).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lactating women: NSSK does not specifically target lactating women, although proper newborn care and feeding practices are likely to be included in the training program.

 

Option B. Children: The Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram (RBSK) is a separate program that focuses on the health of children aged 0 to 18 years, not specifically newborns.

 

Option D. Pregnant women: While pregnant women are an important target group for various maternal health programs, like JSY, JSSK.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Navjat Shishu Suraksha Karyakram (NSSK) is a training program for healthcare personnel at all levels, focusing on the care and resuscitation of newborns (neonates) in the first 7 days of life.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presented to the dermatologist with a small lesion on her right nasolabial fold. Upon examination, the dermatologist noted a 0.4-cm nodule with a smooth surface and well-defined borders. The nodule was located on the upper forehead, just above the eyebrows. It was excised and a pathological examination was done. The image is given below. What is the diagnosis?  (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Basal cell carcinoma

  • The pathological report reveals basal cell carcinoma, a type of skin cancer that is commonly found on sun-exposed areas of the body.
  • Basal cell carcinoma (BCC) is the most common type of skin cancer.
  • It arises from the basal cells, which are found at the bottom of the epidermis. BCCs are typically slow-growing tumors that rarely metastasize but can cause significant local destruction if left untreated.
  • They commonly appear as pearly nodules with visible blood vessels (telangiectasia), often with a central depression or ulceration.
  • They are commonly found in sun-exposed areas, which makes their presence on the face, especially the nasolabial fold, quite typical.
  • Mohs micrographic surgery is one of the most effective treatments for BCC, especially for tumors located in cosmetically sensitive areas, as it ensures complete removal while sparing the maximum amount of healthy tissue.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Melanoma: Melanoma is a more aggressive form of skin cancer that arises from melanocytes, the cells responsible for producing skin pigment. Melanomas are characterized by their asymmetry, irregular borders, multiple colors, diameter greater than 6mm, and evolving size, shape, or color. They can develop from pre-existing moles or appear de novo. Early detection and treatment are crucial as melanoma has a higher potential for metastasis compared to other skin cancers.

 

Option C. Squamous cell carcinoma: Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) is also commonly found in sun-exposed areas and is associated with chronic sun damage. While it is less aggressive than melanoma, if left untreated, it can grow deeply and cause significant damage. In rare cases, it can also spread to other parts of the body. It shows keratin pearls on histopathology.

 

Option D. Nevus: A nevus, commonly known as a mole, is a benign growth on the skin that arises from melanocytes. Moles are usually brown or black and can be located anywhere on the body. They can be present at birth or appear during childhood and adolescence. While most moles are harmless, it is essential to monitor them for changes that might suggest a transformation into melanoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Basal cell carcinoma is the most common type of skin cancer and is typically found in sun-exposed areas.
  • It appears as a pearly nodule with visible blood vessels and can cause significant local destruction if left untreated.
  • Mohs micrographic surgery is an effective treatment, particularly for tumors in cosmetically sensitive areas.

questions.text: Which of the following is contraindicated in Iron overdose? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) BAL

 

BAL (British Anti-Lewisite), also known as Dimercaprol, is contraindicated in cases of iron overdose. This is because BAL forms toxic complexes with iron, which can worsen the patient’s condition. BAL is typically used as a chelating agent for heavy metals like arsenic, mercury (inorganic), and lead, but it is specifically contraindicated in iron, cadmium, selenium, and organic mercury poisoning due to the risk of severe toxicity.

 

The correct treatment for iron overdose is Desferrioxamine, which specifically binds to iron, forming a stable complex that is then excreted from the body. Desferrioxamine is the treatment of choice in acute iron poisoning due to its specific chelation properties for iron.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Desferrioxamine: This is the correct treatment for iron overdose as it binds iron effectively and facilitates its excretion. It is not contraindicated; rather, it is the primary treatment option.

 

Option C. EDTA (Ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid): EDTA is not commonly used for iron overdose, as its primary use is in chelating lead and other heavy metals. While it is not the preferred treatment for iron poisoning, it is not specifically contraindicated as BAL is.

 

Option D. All of the above: This option is incorrect because Desferrioxamine is actually the treatment of choice for iron overdose, and EDTA can be used in some cases if Desferrioxamine is contraindicated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

BAL is contraindicated in iron overdose due to its potential to form harmful complexes, making Desferrioxamine the preferred treatment in such cases.

choices.text: Increase in myocardial oxygen consumption is seen with increased pressure work than volume
Aortic stenosis causes reduced pressure at the aortic valve
Workload has nothing to do with myocardial oxygen consumption
Increased pressure - Increase in preload more than afterload

questions.text: A 50-year-old female presented with dyspnea and chest pain. Which of the following proves that she has aortic stenosis rather than aortic regurgitation? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Increase in myocardial oxygen consumption is seen with increased pressure work than volume

 

In cases of aortic stenosis, the primary issue is the increased afterload due to the obstruction in the aortic valve, which forces the left ventricle to work harder to push blood against the increased resistance. This increased pressure work leads to higher myocardial oxygen consumption because the heart needs more energy to overcome the obstruction. The increase in pressure work (afterload) is significantly more in aortic stenosis than in aortic regurgitation, where volume overload (preload) is more prominent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Aortic stenosis causes reduced pressure at the aortic valve: This statement is incorrect because aortic stenosis actually increases the pressure at the aortic valve due to the obstruction, not reduces it.

 

Option C. Workload has nothing to do with myocardial oxygen consumption: This is incorrect. Myocardial oxygen consumption is directly related to the workload of the heart. Increased workload, especially due to pressure overload in conditions like aortic stenosis, results in higher oxygen consumption.

 

Option D. Increased pressure - Increase in preload more than afterload: This is incorrect because in aortic stenosis, the afterload (pressure) is more significantly increased than the preload. Preload (end-diastolic volume) is typically increased in conditions like aortic regurgitation, not aortic stenosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aortic stenosis is characterized by increased pressure work (afterload) leading to higher myocardial oxygen consumption, distinguishing it from aortic regurgitation, which is associated with volume overload (preload).

questions.text: The maternal use of which of the following hormones is most likely to cause hypospadias in a male child? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Diethylstilbestrol

 

Diethylstilbestrol (DES) is a synthetic estrogen that can disrupt normal fetal development, particularly affecting the reproductive tract. DES exposure during pregnancy, especially around 20 weeks of gestation, is associated with reproductive tract anomalies. Hormonal agents with estrogen-like or progestational effects can interfere with normal genital development in the male fetus, leading to conditions such as hypospadias, where the urethral opening is located on the underside of the penis instead of at the tip.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tolbutamide: This is an oral hypoglycemic agent used to treat diabetes, not a hormone. Tolbutamide does not have significant effects on fetal genital development and has not been linked to hypospadias in male offspring.

 

Option B. Clomiphene: This is an anti-estrogen medication used for ovulation induction. While it affects hormonal pathways, it is not typically administered during pregnancy and has not been documented to cause hypospadias in male offspring.

 

Option D. Clonazepam: This is a benzodiazepine with anxiolytic, anticonvulsant, and sedative properties. Benzodiazepines can cause neonatal effects like hypotonia and withdrawal symptoms, but are not known to cause structural genital abnormalities like hypospadias.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Exposure to hormonal agents during critical periods of fetal development can disrupt normal genital formation, with synthetic estrogens like DES posing particular risk for urogenital abnormalities.

questions.text: Fatty acid transport through mitochondrial membrane is via? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Carnitine

 

Carnitine plays a crucial role in the transport of long-chain fatty acids across the inner mitochondrial membrane for subsequent beta-oxidation. It forms a complex with fatty acids, allowing them to enter the mitochondria.

 

Fatty acid transport into mitochondria from cytoplasm involve the carnitine shuttle system using enzymes Carnitine Palmitoyl Transferase-I (CPT-I) and CPT-II. CPT-I is RLE of fatty acid transport or beta-oxidation of fatty acid.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Acyl carrier protein: Acyl carrier proteins are involved in fatty acid synthesis rather than transport across the mitochondrial membrane. They are essential components of fatty acid biosynthesis pathways.

 

Option C. Cholesterol transporter: Cholesterol transporters primarily facilitate the transport of cholesterol, not fatty acids, across cellular membranes. They are not directly involved in fatty acid transport into mitochondria.

 

Option D. LCAT (Lecithin-Cholesterol Acyltransferase): LCAT is an enzyme responsible for esterifying cholesterol, and it does not play a role in fatty acid transport across the mitochondrial membrane.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fatty acid transport through the mitochondrial membrane involves the carnitine shuttle system. Long-chain fatty acids are activated to form fatty acyl-CoA in the cytoplasm. Carnitine acyltransferase I (CAT I) then catalyzes the transfer of the acyl group from CoA to carnitine, forming fatty acyl-carnitine.

 

Fatty acyl-carnitine is transported across the mitochondrial membrane via a carnitine-acylcarnitine translocase.Once inside the mitochondrial matrix, carnitine acyltransferase II (CAT II) catalyzes the transfer of the acyl group back to CoA, allowing the fatty acid to undergo β-oxidation.

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 208

questions.text: What type of joint is formed between the costal cartilages of the 8th and 9th ribs as they articulate with the 7th rib? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Synovial joint

 

The interchondral joint between the attachment of the 8th and 9th rib with the 7th rib is a synovial joint.

 

  • Synovial joints are characterized by the presence of a synovial cavity containing synovial fluid, which lubricates the joint and allows for a wide range of movement.
  • While costovertebral joints are typically not classified as synovial joints, some costovertebral joints do have a limited degree of synovial joint characteristics, especially in the upper thoracic region.
  • While the costal cartilages themselves are cartilaginous structures, the joints between the 5th to 9th costal cartilages are specifically synovial in nature.
     

Joints in the thoracic cavity are of the following types:

 

  • Synarthrosis- A fibrous band of tissue connects the structures. E.g., 1st sternocostal joint
  • Synchondrosis - primary cartilaginous joints. E.g., costochondral joints
  • Symphysis - secondary cartilaginous joints. E.g., manubriosternal and xiphisternal joints
  • Synovial joints - the presence of these help the thoracic cavity expand during inspiration. E.g.:
    • Interchondral joint
    • Sternocostal joint
    • Costovertebral joint
    • Costotransverse joint

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fibrocartilaginous Joint:

 

  • Fibrocartilaginous joints are characterized by the presence of fibrocartilage, a type of cartilage that contains both fibrous and cartilaginous components.
  • Examples of fibrocartilaginous joints include the intervertebral discs in the spine and the pubic symphysis in the pelvis. These joints allow for limited movement and provide support and shock absorption.

 

Option B. Symphyseal Joint:

 

  • Symphyseal joints are a specific type of cartilaginous joint where two bones are joined by a broad, flat disc of fibrocartilage. These joints are typically immovable or have limited movement.
  • The pubic symphysis, mentioned earlier, is a common example of a symphyseal joint.

 

Option D. Fibrous Joint:

 

  • Fibrous joints are characterized by the presence of fibrous connective tissue between bones. They are immovable or allow for very limited movement.
  • Examples of fibrous joints include the sutures of the skull and the gomphosis joint between the teeth and their sockets.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A person who chronically consumes alcohol and indulged in binge drinking ten days’ back was brought to the hospital. At the presentation, he was unconscious. His Non-Contrast CT scan was normal. His blood glucose came out to be 49 mg/dL. What treatment should be initiated? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) I.m thiamine followed by dextrose

 

Chronic alcohol consumption can lead to thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency due to poor nutritional intake, impaired absorption, and increased requirements. In patients with a history of alcohol dependence who present with hypoglycemia, it is crucial to administer thiamine before giving dextrose. The administration of dextrose without thiamine can precipitate Wernicke's encephalopathy, a serious neurological condition caused by thiamine deficiency. This is because dextrose administration increases the demand for thiamine as it is required for carbohydrate metabolism, thus depleting the already low thiamine reserves.

 

Therefore, thiamine should be given intramuscularly (i.m) first to replenish the body's stores and prevent neurological complications, followed by the administration of dextrose to correct hypoglycemia.

 

Other Options:
